title: Stocks Tread Water Before Jobs Data; Bonds Steady: Markets Wrap
text:
(Bloomberg) -- European stocks gained while U.S. equity futures drifted lower as investors awaited jobs numbers for clues on whether the Federal Reserve will cut rates this month to bolster the world’s largest economy. Government bonds including Treasuries edged higher.

The Stoxx Europe 600 Index climbed, with tech and health care shares leading gains. S&P 500 contracts edged down ahead of Friday’s key monthly American employment report, which comes in the wake of a run of poor data this week that’s strengthened market expectations for a rate cut. Japanese and Australian shares closed higher, while Hong Kong stocks fell as the city invoked emergency powers for the first time in more than half a century to ban face masks for protesters. China remains closed for a holiday. The dollar weakened slightly, and crude oil traded below $53 a barrel in New York.

Today’s figures on the unemployment rate, payroll gains and wages will be closely watched after market pricing for a rate cut surged in the wake of the weakest reading on the U.S. services sector in three years on Thursday. The burst of rate-cut optimism helped snap a two-day losing streak in the S&P 500 Index. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell speaks hours after the Friday morning indicators -- giving him the opportunity of either validating market expectations or walking them back.

India for its part did pull the trigger on another rate cut on Friday, the fifth in the cycle so far. The rupee showed little immediate reaction, while Indian stocks retained a modest advance.

Here are the main moves in markets:

Stocks

Futures on the S&P 500 Index dipped 0.1% as of 9:24 a.m. London time.The Stoxx Europe 600 Index advanced 0.3%.The MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbed 0.1%.The MSCI Emerging Market Index gained 0.1%.

Currencies

The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 0.1%.The euro increased 0.1% to $1.0973.The British pound was little changed at $1.2334.The onshore yuan dipped 0.4% to 7.148 per dollar.The Japanese yen advanced 0.1% to 106.77 per dollar.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasuries declined one basis point to 1.52%.The yield on two-year Treasuries decreased less than one basis point to 1.39%.Germany’s 10-year yield dipped one basis point to -0.60%.Britain’s 10-year yield fell two basis points to 0.455%.Japan’s 10-year yield sank two basis points to -0.211%.

Commodities

West Texas Intermediate crude gained 0.8% to $52.86 a barrel.Iron ore was little changed at $88.55 per metric ton.Gold increased 0.2% to $1,508.60 an ounce.
